explanation.description1: Earth's axis is tilted 23.5 degrees relative to its orbit around the Sun. This tilt stays constant as Earth orbits, always pointing toward the same spot in space (near Polaris).
explanation.description2: When a hemisphere tilts toward the Sun, sunlight hits more directly (concentrated energy = warmer). When tilted away, sunlight hits at a shallow angle (spread out = cooler).
explanation.description3: When the Northern Hemisphere tilts toward the Sun (June), the Southern Hemisphere tilts away. Six months later (December), it's reversed. This is why seasons are always opposite.

seasons.funFact: Fun Fact: Without the tilt, there would be no seasons! Days would always be the same length everywhere.
seasons.notAboutDistanceDesc: A common misconception is that seasons are caused by Earth being closer or farther from the Sun. In fact, Earth is closest to the Sun in January (Northern winter)! The ~3% distance variation has minimal effect compared to the angle of sunlight.

visualModes.subtitle: Understanding cosmic scale
visualModes.whyVisualizationModes: Why we need different visualization modes
visualModes.visualizationChallengeDesc: If the Sun were a <basketball>basketball</basketball>, Earth would be a grain of sand <highlight>26 meters away</highlight>. Neptune? Almost <highlight>a kilometer</highlight>. No screen can show true scale.

scholar.name: Scholar
scholar.description: Logarithmic scaling shows all planets on screen. Perfect for learning orbital positions.

trueSizes.name: True Size
trueSizes.description: Accurate planet sizes relative to each other. Jupiter really is 11x Earth.

trueScale.name: True Scale
trueScale.description: Geometrically perfect. Both sizes and distances use the same scale factor.

truePhysical.name: True Physical Scale
truePhysical.description: Accurate distances and sizes as they exist in space

visualModes.note: Showing the true scale of space is a challenge - if Earth were a marble, the Moon would be 30 feet away, and the Sun would be over a mile away!
